関連科目:
Eastern European Economies, Economic History of the European Union, Introduction to European Economic History.
This class is an English version of "EU Keizai-ron" which will be held in the first half of the spring semester. Students who have already taken any credits of "EU Keizai-ron" are basically not allowed to take this class. If you are eager to take this class, you have to contact SIS office and apply during the course registration period.
授業の概要・背景: The economic integration in the EU has given big impacts on the world economy as well as on the EU itself. And, it will give important lessons when Japan is willing to deepen economic relations with Asian countries. Students will not only understand the EU, but also widen their eyes when they reconsider, for example, the Japanese economy.
授業方法:
The class is held in face to face format.
If you have any questions, please ask them actively during or after each class.

評価.学位授与の方針との関連Relationship to Diploma Polic:
This course is positioned within the curriculum in accordance with the diploma policy and curriculum policy established by International Studies undergraduate school. By proceeding with the study of this course with the awareness of the DP and CP, the following abilities expected by the International Studies undergraduate school will be developed.
European studies:
1. Understanding and analytical skills regarding international issues: the ability to understand and analyze various regions of the world from different perspectives in the humanities and social sciences.
2. Problem-solving skills: the ability to proactively identify problems and solve them based on appropriate methods.
3. Intercultural understanding and multicultural coexistence: the ability to be sensitive to different cultures and to coexist with diverse cultures.

備考　Note
After each lecture, students are asked to submit a note on the lecture. The student will be assessed on the basis of his/her participation in the lecture as well as the note (40%). After each class, students are also asked to submit a report based on a theme set by each student (60%).
